title: 109_s660
content: The "Lumbee Recognition Act" is the short title of this legislation. The preamble of the Act of June 7, 1956 is amended by making specific changes to the wording. The Lumbee Indians of North Carolina, descendants of coastal tribes, have been recognized by the state since 1885 and by Congress in 1956. They are seeking full federal recognition and the benefits that come with it. The Lumbee Tribe, descendants of coastal tribes in North Carolina, are seeking full federal recognition and the benefits that come with it. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina is granted federal recognition under the amended Act of June 7, 1956. This recognition allows them to receive all applicable laws and regulations for Indians and Indian tribes. Additionally, any Indian group in specific counties in North Carolina can petition for acknowledgment of tribal existence if not enrolled in the Lumbee Tribe. Eligibility for services and benefits is also extended to the tribe. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina and its members are eligible for services and benefits provided to federally recognized Indian tribes. Members residing in specific counties are considered to be on or near a reservation. The Secretary of the Interior and Health and Human Services will determine needs and budget in consultation with the tribe after verifying the tribal roll. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina is eligible for federal services and benefits. The Secretary of the Interior and Health and Human Services will determine needs and budget in consultation with the tribe after verifying the tribal roll. The Lumbee Tribe's eligibility for federal services and benefits is based on their constitution adopted in 2000, with verification to be completed within 1 year of enactment. The Lumbee Tribe seeks to convey fee land to the United States for trust, to be treated as on-reservation trust acquisitions if located in Robeson County, North Carolina. State jurisdiction is addressed in the following section. The State of North Carolina has jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions on land owned by the Lumbee Tribe or any dependent Indian community. The Secretary of the Interior can accept jurisdiction transfers from the state to the United States under an agreement with the tribe. The Lumbee Tribe's jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions on their land in North Carolina can be transferred to the United States under an agreement with the Secretary of the Interior, but the transfer will not take effect until 2 years after the agreement's effective date. This transfer does not impact the application of the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978. Authorization of appropriations is granted for the implementation of this Act.
